name.value: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus > Effects of giving causal explanation for behavioural advice

other.value:
We will run exploratory analyses investigating the effects of numeracy as well as socio-economic status (including education) and demographics as different sections of the population may engage differently with the various treatments.
Furthermore, as COVID-19 is a highly emotive/current topic at the moment, we will investigate the effects that opinions and attitudes on the virus (such as state of concern, and trust in policies/political leaders/official communication) as well as the extent to which participants are personally affected, and their prosocial inclinations and self-efficacy views have on our measures.
We will also compare effects across various countries in which we are planning to run this study.

sample.value: We will sample 700 participants (per country), providing 95% power at alpha level 0.05 for small effects.

analyses.value: We will run generalized linear models (including OLS, ANOVA and ANCOVA). We will compare effects between our three experimental groups, with a focus on potential differences between the two explanation groups. We will correct for multiple comparisons with Tukey. We will run balance checks to ensure that random assignment successfully balanced demographic and other background variables across our experimental groups. If groups are unbalanced, we will control for these imbalances. We will run separate models for the two differing public health communications to explore potential differences in effects. If effects ‘replicate’ between the scenarios, i.e. if there are no significant differences between the two communication messages we will pool the data.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who do not complete our survey. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail an attention check (i.e. a measure that asks participants to indicate the info that was provided in the intervention text; as those participants who cannot provide this information likely did not read the text which makes their data not-usable).

dependent.value: Key dependent variables are affective reaction (‘How does the info you just saw make you feel?’, slider neg to pos, 10 points), comprehension (‘How easy/difficult do you find this information to understand’, 7 point scale), trust (‘To what extent do you think this advice is trustworthy?’, 7 point scale), and action intent (‘How likely are you to take this advice?’, 7 point scale).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three above described conditions, i.e. control, expl no source, expl scientific source. Additionally, every participant will receive both public health communication messages in a randomized order.

hypothesis.value: In this study we are testing the effects of providing an explanation for a recommended public health action on affect, comprehension, trust, and personal action intention. Specifically, we are comparing effects between providing no explanatory information (control), providing explanatory information without mentioning a source (expl no source), and providing explanatory information with mentioning a scientific source (expl scientific source). We are testing these questions using two different public health communication messages; one on the importance of social distancing if someone is coughing or sneezing, and one on the importance of quarantining if symptoms persist.

name.value: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus > Analysis of confidence in estimating numbers affected

analyses.value:
Regressions will be calculated to predict the dependent variables described under “Confidence interval estimation” in the previous section, for a total of 13 regressions (one for size of point estimate on each question, one for accuracy on each question, one for confidence interval width on each question, and one for overall calibration score), using the following independent variables:

- numeracy (high vs. low numeracy, using the Berlin Numeracy Test)
- education level (university vs. no university)
- status as a healthcare provider vs. non-healthcare provider

This analysis will also be conducted separately for respondents from different countries.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who do not complete our survey. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail an attention check (i.e. a measure that asks participants to indicate the info that was provided in the intervention text; as those participants who cannot provide this information likely did not read the text which makes their data not-usable). We will also screen the data for suspicious scoring patterns across the survey (such as scoring “7” on a long consecutive series of items, including reverse coded items), and may exclude people with such scoring patterns.

dependent.value:
- size of participant’s estimate (analysed separately for each question; for each question, higher answers are more pessimistic than lower answers (as questions concern expected # of deaths, fatalities, & infection rate))
- accuracy (difference between participant’s point estimate and actual answer, calculated and analysed separately for each question)
- participant’s 75% confidence interval width (top of confidence interval minus bottom of confidence interval, calculated and analysed separately for each question)
- calibration scores (75% minus proportion of the 4 confidence interval questions answered correctly); positive scores indicate overconfidence in ability to correctly predict the future, negative scores indicate underconfidence; 0 is perfectly calibrated

attributes.title: Early Opioid Policy Response
attributes.description: This study is an attempt to understand the impact that enacting legislation may have had on state-level opioid prescription rates. It uses publicly available data to draw comparisons between Minnesota and other states that either have or have not enacted their own legislation to combat the proliferation of prescription opioids.

q1.value: Evaluation of State Legislative Responses to the Opioid Abuse Epidemic

q2.value: Sean Linnaeus Barton, Aaron T. Berger, Anna Solmeyer, Muizz Alaradi, Weston Merrick, Mikaela Binsfeld, Benjamin Nguyen, Ian Williamson

q3.value:
The late 1990s saw an increase in the number of healthcare providers prescribing opioid pain relievers, as well as an increase in the number of pills that were prescribed. This culminated in the early 2010s, when the opioid prescribing rate in the United States reached 81.2 prescriptions per 100 people (1). With numerous opioid pain relievers available, opioid overdose rates began spiking across the United States. In 2016, 11.5 million Americans ages 12 or older reported misusing prescription opioids (2). By 2017, 68% of drug overdose deaths involved opioids (3). 

In recent years there have been a number of federal and state policy responses to the opioid abuse crisis. Federal responses have included increasing access to addiction treatment, ensuring overdose-reversing drugs are available to high-risk populations, strengthening public health data reporting and collection, supporting research to understand the problem and find solutions, and advancing pain management and evidence-based pain care (7). The federal government has also streamlined the efforts of several agencies to coordinate responses and address priority areas (8). Strategies include expanded access to naloxone and allowing qualified primary care practitioners, who obtain a waiver, to provide medication-assisted treatment for up to 275 patients (9). 

Within this broader national response, states have begun to implement their own plans and programs to address problematic opioid use and opioid harm within their communities. State-level responses are uniquely important because they are better able to target regional and cultural contributors to community crises. State-responses can be less one-size-fits-all than federal policies, and thus may more effectively address the opioid crisis for citizens of that state. In addition to greater policy specificity, states can encourage social change through the passage of policies, independent of the specific actions of the policies. Because citizens are more directly affected by state-level policies and programs, the passage of policies at the state level provides a signal to the community about the state’s priorities and changes to its social environment. The adoption of a program may encourage changes in community behavior before the program is even initiated as citizens of the state respond to the perceived shift in state priorities. 

Prominent examples of state-level approaches that have been shown to impact opioid abuse and harm include provisions for Good Samaritan immunity (10), increased availability of rescue drugs, healthcare provider training, and licensing and regulation of pain management facilities (11). Of the variety of state policy responses, two common approaches have focused on moderating opioid prescribing in order to address problems specifically related to prescription opioid drugs (12). 

The earliest state policy responses aimed at moderating opioid prescribing established enhanced prescription drug monitoring programs (PDMPs) to track prescribing behavior and prescription utilization trends. PDMPs gather electronic information about a patient's history of prescriptions, and potential for misuse, from prescribers and pharmaceutical dispensaries when a prescription is issued. While the utility and impact of PDMPs should not be understated, most state PDMPs were established before the scope and importance of the national opioid crisis was evident. However, many states made an array of changes, including tightening up requirements around use before prescribing, requiring course treatments, and expanding the contexts under which the PDMP must be used. Establishment of PDMPs has been associated with a reduction in opioid poisoning and healthcare admissions for opioid-related treatment (13). States with strict PDMP utilization requirements (specifically, those that have a mandatory requirement that physicians check before issuing at least some opioid prescriptions) have also seen a reduction in opioid prescribing (14). 

A second approach directly targeting prescription opioids is the adoption of regulatory limits on opioid prescribing. The Centers for Disease Control's 2016 Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Chronic Pain noted that long-term use often begins with treating acute pain, but a three- to seven-day supply is usually enough for severe pain (15). Shortly after the release of these guidelines, Massachusetts became the first state to adopt a seven-day statutory limit on initial opioid prescriptions (16). At least 33 states enacted legislative opioid prescribing limits, including both limits on all first-time opioid prescriptions and limits affecting only certain prescriptions (e.g., prescriptions for dental or ophthalmologic pain), by October 2018 (17). 

Prescribing limits provide an important opportunity to understand the impact of state-level signaling of a crisis response through the implementation of legislation. Because of broad public awareness of the opioid crisis by 2016, state-level adoption of prescribing limits had a greater potential for public visibility than typical state legislation. These policies also specifically targeted the prescription opioid crisis, and thus provided a concrete signal of a state’s intent to change problematic prescribing behavior. Finally, because these policies were implemented at the state level (and not all states have implemented such policies) there is an opportunity to understand how the signaling of a state-level response to a national problem impacts the residents of those states. 

The purpose of this evaluation is to estimate the causal effect of the passage of state-level opioid monitoring programs (i.e., prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use) and prescription limiting legislation on the volume of prescribing for opioid drugs and the rate of fatal opioid poisonings. This evaluation will provide policy makers with an understanding of national trends in opioid prescribing, opioid-related death rates, and the role that state legislation has played in shaping those trends. 

Primary Research Question: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level Medicaid opioid prescription rate, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Secondary Research Question 1: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level drug poisoning death rate for prescription opioids, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Secondary Research Question 2: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level drug poisoning death rate for all types of opioids, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Exploratory Research Questions: We will examine several potential moderators of the association between legislative action and prescription rates and drug poisoning deaths due to opioids. These include: the state’s baseline rate of Medicaid opioid prescribing, the state’s baseline rate of drug poisoning deaths due to opioids, and the state’s demographic characteristics.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level Medicaid will tend towards lower prescribing rates, compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.

Hypothesis 2: In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level opioid drug-poisoning death rates (due to prescription opioids) will tend towards lower death rates, compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.

Hypothesis 3:  In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level opioid drug-poisoning death rates (due to all types of opioids) will tend towards lower death rates compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study design for this evaluation is a natural experimental design in which states are the unit of observation, and the adoption of a policy change is the exposure. No states adopted PDMP laws requiring physicians to review PDMP records before Nevada, in 2007. Massachusetts passed the first opioid prescribing limits in 2016. Many states adopted similar policies following these states' lead. 

The identification strategy is a generalized difference-in-differences approach, using event study methodology, that includes a linear two-way (state and time period) fixed effects regression with leads and lags of treatment (18). We will estimate the time-varying effect of adopting each policy during the year of adoption, and one, two, and three or more years after adoption. Levels of opioid prescribing and drug poisoning death rates in each state at each time period will be compared to outcomes in other states that either had not yet adopted similar policies or did not adopt similar policies before the end of the study period. As of the fall of 2019, six states have adopted neither a prescriber mandate for PDMP use nor statutory prescription limits. As recently as the beginning of 2017, seventeen states had not adopted either policy. Categorical state, year, and (when appropriate) quarter fixed effects, as well as fixed effects for state-level time-varying confounders including both annual demographic and economic characteristics, and state-level policies such as marijuana liberalization and Medicaid expansion, will be used to control for fixed and time-varying confounding effects. 

The event study specification makes three essential assumptions (19) that must be satisfied for causal effect identification: 

1. Parallel baseline trends are independent of exposure status. In counterfactual notation, the conditional exchangeability assumption can be written as Ya⫫A|L, which is to say that the outcome a state would have experienced (Y), at any given time with any given combination of state opioid policies (a), is independent (⫫) of the actual set of state opioid policies that the state had at that time (A), given the identified confounding variables (L). This assumption is untestable in any difference-in-difference analysis, because states are not randomized to receive the policies. However, the absence of pre-policy differential trends lends support to the assumption that post-policy trends would have been parallel if the policies had not been adopted. 

2. No anticipatory behavior prior to treatment. This is an extension of the parallel trends assumption. It holds that for all lead periods l<0, the effect of approaching treatment μ_l is 0. This is most plausible for random (exogenous) exposures. While it is reasonable to assume that prescribers and/or opioid users would not change their behavior in anticipation of upcoming legislation, it would not be unreasonable for states with worsening opioid-related outcomes to adopt more stringent controls. Either reason for pre-trends would bias estimated effects. We did not find evidence of differential trends in policy adopting states in the years prior to policy adoption. 

3. Treatment effect homogeneity. For each "cohort" of policy implementations, the effect μ_l of being in a relative timing lag period l≥0 is homogeneous regardless of absolute timing t. This assumption can only be tested in the final analysis. The presence of heterogeneous treatment effects does not invalidate results, but rather results in a weighted average of time-varying treatment effects. Several important differences exist between state-years with policies and state-years without policies (see Figure 1 for a Directed Acyclic Graph displaying these variables). As an impact evaluation seeking to estimate the causal effect of state opioid policies on opioid prescribing and opioid-related deaths, this evaluation depends on an assumption of conditional exchangeability between states that did, and did not, adopt opioid policies of interest. According to this assumption, no unmeasured confounding variables are directly associated with state opioid policies and the outcome of interest, conditional on the measured confounding variables. 

Several unmeasured time-invariant characteristics of each state (labeled "V" in Figure 1) may be linked to the outcome after policy change. For example, each state has a fixed baseline rate of the outcome that is associated with the outcome at any follow-up time. We include state fixed effects to account for these characteristics.

Within states, changes in the age structure of the population, the racial/ethnic composition of the population, the prevailing unemployment rate and employment in the manufacturing sector, and the passage of other relevant laws, such as marijuana liberalization, Medicaid expansion, and opioid-related policies such as Good Samaritan laws and naloxone access laws, may be associated both with the adoption of relevant policies and with either prescriber behavior or the risk of opioid-related mortality. 

Finally, national trends across time (labeled "U" in Figure 1), such as changing levels of opioid prescribing and mortality may also be linked to the outcome after policy change. We include year fixed effects to account for these national trends. Because national trends are not neatly summarized with a linear or quadratic trend, we will include a categorical year fixed effect.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
State opioid policies: Several sources were used to code state opioid policies. The primary source for state opioid prescribing limits was a National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL) table of state prescribing limits, (20) which summarized policies enacted through April 4, 2018. Information on subsequent legislation was available through NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (21) and Ballotpedia's summary of opioid prescription limits and policies by state (22). Information on state PDMP prescriber use mandates was found in the supplement (23) to an article by Haffajee, et al., 2018 (24). That article coded PDMP policies passed through 2014; we extended their coding scheme forward for policies passed between 2015 and 2019 and included in NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (25). Detailed information on policy coding is included in Section 4, Variables. 

Opioid prescribing rates: Our primary source will be the Medicaid State Drug Utilization Data, available quarterly from 1991 to current. 

Fatal opioid poisonings: Detailed Multiple Cause of Death research files (monthly by county, 2006 to current). Opioid drug poisoning rates due to all types of opioids will be calculated using ICD-10 underlying cause codes T40.0 through T40.4 and T40.6, which refer to poisoning by opium (T40.0), heroin (T40.1), "other opioids" including natural and semi-synthetic opioids (T40.2), methadone (T40.3), synthetic opioids such as fentanyl (T40.4), and "other and unspecified narcotics" (T40.6). Code T40.5, which refers to poisoning by cocaine, is excluded as it is legally classified as a narcotic drug but is not an opioid. For secondary question 1, prescription opioids will be defined narrowly as ICD-10 code T40.2, which includes natural opioids (e.g. morphine, codeine) and semi-synthetic opioids (e.g. hydrocodone, oxycodone), which make up the majority of opioid pain killer medications (26). 

Covariates: American Community Survey (supplemented with Current Population Survey data for 2006-2007 and 2019), Ballotpedia, FRED economic data, National Conference of State Legislatures, Prescription Drug Abuse Policy System, Urban Institute.

q13.value: This study utilizes publicly available administrative data for measures of opioid prescribing rates across all 50 states in the United States. Further, our research questions (as stated above) are focused on the impact of individual state policies within the states that enacted them. As such, the study population is fixed and adjustments to study sample sizes to improve statistical power are not possible. However, it is still informative to understand the expected power of the study as it is implemented, as this provides context for interpreting results regardless of statistical significance. Additionally, a power analysis provides an illustration of the minimum detectable effects (MDE) within each study period of interest to our work.

q14.value:
We performed our power analysis via simulation using the “simstudy” (27) package in R to generate artificial data from estimates of the population distribution around the parameters to be fit by our event study model. We used these estimates to simulate realistic variance around the parameters of a data generating function (in this case our statistical model), introduced a defined policy effect to a particular event period, and then used our model to test for the presence of the effect. For each introduced effect, we simulated 1000 possible experiments, drawing data from the estimated distributions, and calculated power as the proportion of those simulations where effects were correctly detected.

Our study is concerned with the change in opioid-related outcomes after states enact legislation targeting the opioid problem. We therefore used the data collected in our study for the event periods prior to the policy event to estimate the expected means and variances (in absence of a policy effect) after the policy was enacted. The implicit assumption made by this approach is that event periods after the policy has been enacted will only differ from periods before the policy is enacted if there is a policy effect. Introduced effects were standardized and scaled between -0.6 to 0.6 (i.e., making no assumptions about effect direction). 

To provide the most parsimonious and interpretable estimate of a minimum detectable effect, we only introduced an effect in one event period at a time, keeping effects in all other simulated event periods fixed at zero. This choice was made to limit the number of conditions that needed to be simulated (a combinatorial grid search of all possible effect sizes in all possible event periods quickly becomes computationally intractable), as well as in recognition of the fact that effects in multiple event periods are cumulative (though not linearly) in terms of the model’s ability to detect an effect. Thus, a small effect in a single event period (with all others held at zero) represents the worst-case scenario for our model’s ability to detect an effect in the data. Importantly, the situation where an effect exists in one event period to the exclusion of all others is highly unlikely in practice and would be difficult to interpret in the context of our study. An example of an isolated simulated experiment for an effect introduced in event period “Lead1” can be seen in Figure 2 above (Illustrated Effect Test). Note that event period “Lag1” is set as the intercept of our model (and thus effects and variance are scaled to this event period), and that effects and variance in event periods prior to “Lag1” are measured from our study data. 

Figure 3 above (Power Analysis and MDE) illustrates the results of our power analysis for the prescription rate outcome, with curves showing the relationship between effect size and power for effects in each event period after a policy is introduced. Vertical dashed lines (colored) isolate the minimum detectable effect for a given event period at a required power of 0.8. Curves are not exactly symmetric, as prescribing trends prior to policy events are non-zero. Small to medium effects are more difficult to detect for event periods that are further away in time from the period of policy enactment. This makes sense, as the sample size decreases further from the event periods as many states have only enacted policies recently. 

It is important to highlight that our investigation of power and MDE in this study is not a calculation of post-hoc power. It is well known that post-hoc power is a largely uninformative statistical measure that provides little additional information beyond the result of the statistical test used in a study. Here, we do not use any data from states after a policy has been implemented to estimate our distribution in the simulation. By only using data collected prior to policy implementation, we are implicitly treating those years before a policy is implemented as a pilot study for the years after a policy is implemented. We then adopt an assumption that state's prescribing after a policy is passed is well modeled by their behavior before the policy is passed, so long as no policy effects are present. The strength of our estimate of power and MDE is conditioned on this assumption, in the same way that a power analysis in using pilot study data is conditioned on the agreement between the pilot study and the full study.

question.value:
Two major categories of state opioid prescribing policies were coded for this impact evaluation: statutory limits on opioid prescribing, and mandates for prescribers to request data from a state's PDMP. The coding scheme for specific policies is shown in Table 1. 

Statutory limits on opioid prescribing: The primary source of information for coding statutory limits on opioid prescribing was a summary table prepared by the NCSL (29). The NCSL summary table described prescription limiting statutes adopted in 21 states between the first such policy, passed in Massachusetts in 2016, and April 4, 2018. A link to the enabling legislation is included along with a short description of the limitations/requirements and any exceptions to requirements. The NCSL summary table also noted that laws had been passed in nine other states, to authorize another entity to set prescribing limits or guidelines. We filled in the remaining gaps through reference to the nonpartisan online political encyclopedia Ballotpedia, (30) and direct coding of adopted state laws receiving a code of "Prescription Drug Abuse, Prescribing Guidelines/Limits" in NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database, (31) which extends through 2019. State policies were independently coded by separate analysts, with consensus resolution of any discrepancies. 

Prescriber mandates for PDMP use: The primary source of information used to develop the coding framework for PDMP prescriber mandates came from an article by Haffajee, et al., which coded PDMP policies in all states through 2014 (32). We extended the coding scheme forward through 2019 using NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (34). Codes were checked against each state's profile as described by the Prescription Drug Monitoring Program Training and Technical Assistance Center (35). 

Exposure coding: Coding of the two types of state policy interventions will be collapsed into two levels per policy, as shown in Table 1:

 - Statutory limits on opioid prescribing will be collapsed into "some prescription limits" or "no statutory limit/guidelines only." States with statutory limits on all initial opioid prescriptions, statutory limits on certain opioid prescriptions (such as those for emergency room walk-in patients), or enforceable limits set by another agency on all or certain opioid prescriptions, will be coded as having some prescription limits. States with nonbinding guidelines or no policy will be coded as not having prescription limits. 

- Prescriber mandates for PDMP use policies will be collapsed into "PDMP use mandate" or "no PDMP use mandate." States with laws requiring physicians to consult the PDMP before writing all or some opioid prescriptions will be coded as having a PDMP use mandate. States allowing prescribers to access the PDMP but not mandating such access, or states with no PDMP available to prescribers, will be coded as not having a PDMP use mandate. 

Finally, we will test the effect of passing either type of legislation by assigning an exposure of 1 if a state has passed either a statutory limit on opioid prescribing or a prescriber mandates for PDMP use; and a 0 if a state has passed neither such policy.

Publicly Available outcome data: 

- Medicaid State Drug Utilization Data. The National Drug Code (NDC) will be used to identify opioid medications in the Medicaid State Drug Utilization data. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have released a data file permitting the conversion of prescription opioid medications to Morphine Milligram Equivalents (MME). The total MME for each state-year can therefore be calculated and standardized to the number of Medicaid patients in the state that year.

- National Center for Health Statistics Detailed Multiple Cause of Death research files. ICD-10 underlying cause-of-death codes will be analyzed to identify annual statewide deaths related to common prescription opioid medications and to all opioid drugs. The number of deaths will be treated as a Poisson random variable. 

Covariates: To prevent bias due to omitted variables that may be associated with both policy exposure and opioid prescribing and drug poisoning outcomes, the impact analysis will control for 1) additional, related state-level policies (e.g., state Medicaid expansion status and marijuana liberalization, as both medical and recreational uses), 2) state-level demographic characteristics (e.g., proportion of state residents in banded age categories and race/ethnicity categories), 3) state-level economic data (e.g., statewide unemployment rate). We will also include 4) state fixed effects to control for non-time varying unobserved heterogeneity, and 5) yearly, categorical fixed effects to control for nonlinear national trends in the outcome in states that have not adopted policies of interest. 

When a data source covers only a portion of the time period of interest (for example, ACS includes Medicaid coverage only for 2008-2018), we used regression techniques to impute missing values from alternate data sources (e.g. CPS, a smaller sample with a slightly different measure of Medicaid coverage). Additionally, because sampling-based estimation like the ACS (which is a representative 1% sample of the population each year) are subject to random error, this causes estimates to be more variable in low-population states. Therefore, we used linear mixed models to obtain smoothed estimates of time-varying demographic covariates in each state. State time-varying covariates are listed in Table 2.

The impact of each opioid policy will be estimated by comparing the changes in outcomes for states that passed the policy, to the outcomes of states that did not pass, or had not yet passed, the policy. These comparisons will be conducted using models that account for correlated residuals due to repeated observations of states. 

The following model will be fitted to the sample of students in the study, with states (i) observed at multiple time points (t):

Y_it = λ_t+α_i+∑_(l= -K)^L〖μ_l D_it^l 〗+X_it+ϵ_it

The variables in this model are defined as follows: 

Y_it = The outcome of interest Y (or a linear transformation such as a log link function for a Poisson random variable) for state i measured at time t. 

λ_t = Fixed effect for time t accounting for time trends in as-yet-untreated states. 

α_i = Fixed effect for state i accounting for unmeasured time-invariant covariates. 

l = Lead or lag times l, relative to policy adoption, with leads ranging from 1 to K or more years prior to policy passage, and lags ranging from 0 to L or more years after policy passage. 

μ_l = The mean difference-in-differences for a given lead or lag time. 

D_it^l = A series of binomial indicators indicating if a state-year observation is l years before or after policy passage. To avoid multicollinearity, the indicator for a reference lead time (l = -1) is omitted. 

X_it = A vector of state level, time-varying covariates. 

ϵ_it = State-level residual variation of outcome Y at time t.

q21.value: The statistical significance of difference-in-difference estimates will be assessed using a two-tailed t-test. 95% confidence intervals will be presented in tables, with statistical significance indicated if the 95% confidence interval excludes the null.

In the Medicaid State Drug Utilization data, all data with cell counts under 11 are suppressed. We will use an appropriate method for replacing these missing data without biasing variance estimates of the overall opioid drug prescription rate. For example, 10/√2 can be substituted for suppressed counts if the unsuppressed data are normally distributed, and 5 can be substituted for suppressed counts if unsuppressed data are lognormally distributed. Because suppressed prescribing quantities are aggregated with unsuppressed quantities of other drugs within states, single number substitution of drugs with suppressed prescribing rates will minimally bias the overall opioid drug prescribing rate. 

A small number of state-quarters of data in the Medicaid State Drug Utilization data were also either missing entirely or contained obviously erroneous reports (such as over 1,000 prescriptions per Medicaid recipient). These quarters were flagged and excluded from analysis. Because the final analysis data will be aggregated to the year, we will exclude that state-year and use maximum likelihood estimation to account for the missing outcome.

In order to convert the number of prescriptions into morphine milligram equivalents of the drug, we must impute the number of units (typically, single pills) for each suppressed observation. We will do this by fitting a linear model, for each drug code, relating the unsuppressed number of prescriptions to the unsuppressed number of units of that drug. That linear model will be used to estimate the number of units that would have been reported, had the suppressed observations not been suppressed. Because each suppressed observation, by definition, accounts for few prescriptions, we anticipate that substitution and single imputation will not substantially bias standard errors.

registration_responses.q1: Evaluation of State Legislative Responses to the Opioid Abuse Epidemic
registration_responses.q2: Sean Linnaeus Barton, Aaron T. Berger, Anna Solmeyer, Muizz Alaradi, Weston Merrick, Mikaela Binsfeld, Benjamin Nguyen, Ian Williamson
registration_responses.q3:
The late 1990s saw an increase in the number of healthcare providers prescribing opioid pain relievers, as well as an increase in the number of pills that were prescribed. This culminated in the early 2010s, when the opioid prescribing rate in the United States reached 81.2 prescriptions per 100 people (1). With numerous opioid pain relievers available, opioid overdose rates began spiking across the United States. In 2016, 11.5 million Americans ages 12 or older reported misusing prescription opioids (2). By 2017, 68% of drug overdose deaths involved opioids (3). 

In recent years there have been a number of federal and state policy responses to the opioid abuse crisis. Federal responses have included increasing access to addiction treatment, ensuring overdose-reversing drugs are available to high-risk populations, strengthening public health data reporting and collection, supporting research to understand the problem and find solutions, and advancing pain management and evidence-based pain care (7). The federal government has also streamlined the efforts of several agencies to coordinate responses and address priority areas (8). Strategies include expanded access to naloxone and allowing qualified primary care practitioners, who obtain a waiver, to provide medication-assisted treatment for up to 275 patients (9). 

Within this broader national response, states have begun to implement their own plans and programs to address problematic opioid use and opioid harm within their communities. State-level responses are uniquely important because they are better able to target regional and cultural contributors to community crises. State-responses can be less one-size-fits-all than federal policies, and thus may more effectively address the opioid crisis for citizens of that state. In addition to greater policy specificity, states can encourage social change through the passage of policies, independent of the specific actions of the policies. Because citizens are more directly affected by state-level policies and programs, the passage of policies at the state level provides a signal to the community about the state’s priorities and changes to its social environment. The adoption of a program may encourage changes in community behavior before the program is even initiated as citizens of the state respond to the perceived shift in state priorities. 

Prominent examples of state-level approaches that have been shown to impact opioid abuse and harm include provisions for Good Samaritan immunity (10), increased availability of rescue drugs, healthcare provider training, and licensing and regulation of pain management facilities (11). Of the variety of state policy responses, two common approaches have focused on moderating opioid prescribing in order to address problems specifically related to prescription opioid drugs (12). 

The earliest state policy responses aimed at moderating opioid prescribing established enhanced prescription drug monitoring programs (PDMPs) to track prescribing behavior and prescription utilization trends. PDMPs gather electronic information about a patient's history of prescriptions, and potential for misuse, from prescribers and pharmaceutical dispensaries when a prescription is issued. While the utility and impact of PDMPs should not be understated, most state PDMPs were established before the scope and importance of the national opioid crisis was evident. However, many states made an array of changes, including tightening up requirements around use before prescribing, requiring course treatments, and expanding the contexts under which the PDMP must be used. Establishment of PDMPs has been associated with a reduction in opioid poisoning and healthcare admissions for opioid-related treatment (13). States with strict PDMP utilization requirements (specifically, those that have a mandatory requirement that physicians check before issuing at least some opioid prescriptions) have also seen a reduction in opioid prescribing (14). 

A second approach directly targeting prescription opioids is the adoption of regulatory limits on opioid prescribing. The Centers for Disease Control's 2016 Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Chronic Pain noted that long-term use often begins with treating acute pain, but a three- to seven-day supply is usually enough for severe pain (15). Shortly after the release of these guidelines, Massachusetts became the first state to adopt a seven-day statutory limit on initial opioid prescriptions (16). At least 33 states enacted legislative opioid prescribing limits, including both limits on all first-time opioid prescriptions and limits affecting only certain prescriptions (e.g., prescriptions for dental or ophthalmologic pain), by October 2018 (17). 

Prescribing limits provide an important opportunity to understand the impact of state-level signaling of a crisis response through the implementation of legislation. Because of broad public awareness of the opioid crisis by 2016, state-level adoption of prescribing limits had a greater potential for public visibility than typical state legislation. These policies also specifically targeted the prescription opioid crisis, and thus provided a concrete signal of a state’s intent to change problematic prescribing behavior. Finally, because these policies were implemented at the state level (and not all states have implemented such policies) there is an opportunity to understand how the signaling of a state-level response to a national problem impacts the residents of those states. 

The purpose of this evaluation is to estimate the causal effect of the passage of state-level opioid monitoring programs (i.e., prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use) and prescription limiting legislation on the volume of prescribing for opioid drugs and the rate of fatal opioid poisonings. This evaluation will provide policy makers with an understanding of national trends in opioid prescribing, opioid-related death rates, and the role that state legislation has played in shaping those trends. 

Primary Research Question: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level Medicaid opioid prescription rate, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Secondary Research Question 1: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level drug poisoning death rate for prescription opioids, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Secondary Research Question 2: Among Medicaid recipients in all 50 states, does passage of a state-level legislative action regarding prescription drug monitoring programs and/or limitations on opioid prescribing lead to a change in the state-level drug poisoning death rate for all types of opioids, relative to the rate in other states or time periods when there is no law in place? 

Exploratory Research Questions: We will examine several potential moderators of the association between legislative action and prescription rates and drug poisoning deaths due to opioids. These include: the state’s baseline rate of Medicaid opioid prescribing, the state’s baseline rate of drug poisoning deaths due to opioids, and the state’s demographic characteristics.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level Medicaid will tend towards lower prescribing rates, compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.

Hypothesis 2: In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level opioid drug-poisoning death rates (due to prescription opioids) will tend towards lower death rates, compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.

Hypothesis 3:  In states that pass prescriber mandates for prescription drug monitoring use and/or limitations on opioid prescribing, changes in state-level opioid drug-poisoning death rates (due to all types of opioids) will tend towards lower death rates compared to states and time periods where such rigorous policies are not in place.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q13: This study utilizes publicly available administrative data for measures of opioid prescribing rates across all 50 states in the United States. Further, our research questions (as stated above) are focused on the impact of individual state policies within the states that enacted them. As such, the study population is fixed and adjustments to study sample sizes to improve statistical power are not possible. However, it is still informative to understand the expected power of the study as it is implemented, as this provides context for interpreting results regardless of statistical significance. Additionally, a power analysis provides an illustration of the minimum detectable effects (MDE) within each study period of interest to our work.
registration_responses.q14:
We performed our power analysis via simulation using the “simstudy” (27) package in R to generate artificial data from estimates of the population distribution around the parameters to be fit by our event study model. We used these estimates to simulate realistic variance around the parameters of a data generating function (in this case our statistical model), introduced a defined policy effect to a particular event period, and then used our model to test for the presence of the effect. For each introduced effect, we simulated 1000 possible experiments, drawing data from the estimated distributions, and calculated power as the proportion of those simulations where effects were correctly detected.

Our study is concerned with the change in opioid-related outcomes after states enact legislation targeting the opioid problem. We therefore used the data collected in our study for the event periods prior to the policy event to estimate the expected means and variances (in absence of a policy effect) after the policy was enacted. The implicit assumption made by this approach is that event periods after the policy has been enacted will only differ from periods before the policy is enacted if there is a policy effect. Introduced effects were standardized and scaled between -0.6 to 0.6 (i.e., making no assumptions about effect direction). 

To provide the most parsimonious and interpretable estimate of a minimum detectable effect, we only introduced an effect in one event period at a time, keeping effects in all other simulated event periods fixed at zero. This choice was made to limit the number of conditions that needed to be simulated (a combinatorial grid search of all possible effect sizes in all possible event periods quickly becomes computationally intractable), as well as in recognition of the fact that effects in multiple event periods are cumulative (though not linearly) in terms of the model’s ability to detect an effect. Thus, a small effect in a single event period (with all others held at zero) represents the worst-case scenario for our model’s ability to detect an effect in the data. Importantly, the situation where an effect exists in one event period to the exclusion of all others is highly unlikely in practice and would be difficult to interpret in the context of our study. An example of an isolated simulated experiment for an effect introduced in event period “Lead1” can be seen in Figure 2 above (Illustrated Effect Test). Note that event period “Lag1” is set as the intercept of our model (and thus effects and variance are scaled to this event period), and that effects and variance in event periods prior to “Lag1” are measured from our study data. 

Figure 3 above (Power Analysis and MDE) illustrates the results of our power analysis for the prescription rate outcome, with curves showing the relationship between effect size and power for effects in each event period after a policy is introduced. Vertical dashed lines (colored) isolate the minimum detectable effect for a given event period at a required power of 0.8. Curves are not exactly symmetric, as prescribing trends prior to policy events are non-zero. Small to medium effects are more difficult to detect for event periods that are further away in time from the period of policy enactment. This makes sense, as the sample size decreases further from the event periods as many states have only enacted policies recently. 

It is important to highlight that our investigation of power and MDE in this study is not a calculation of post-hoc power. It is well known that post-hoc power is a largely uninformative statistical measure that provides little additional information beyond the result of the statistical test used in a study. Here, we do not use any data from states after a policy has been implemented to estimate our distribution in the simulation. By only using data collected prior to policy implementation, we are implicitly treating those years before a policy is implemented as a pilot study for the years after a policy is implemented. We then adopt an assumption that state's prescribing after a policy is passed is well modeled by their behavior before the policy is passed, so long as no policy effects are present. The strength of our estimate of power and MDE is conditioned on this assumption, in the same way that a power analysis in using pilot study data is conditioned on the agreement between the pilot study and the full study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study design for this evaluation is a natural experimental design in which states are the unit of observation, and the adoption of a policy change is the exposure. No states adopted PDMP laws requiring physicians to review PDMP records before Nevada, in 2007. Massachusetts passed the first opioid prescribing limits in 2016. Many states adopted similar policies following these states' lead. 

The identification strategy is a generalized difference-in-differences approach, using event study methodology, that includes a linear two-way (state and time period) fixed effects regression with leads and lags of treatment (18). We will estimate the time-varying effect of adopting each policy during the year of adoption, and one, two, and three or more years after adoption. Levels of opioid prescribing and drug poisoning death rates in each state at each time period will be compared to outcomes in other states that either had not yet adopted similar policies or did not adopt similar policies before the end of the study period. As of the fall of 2019, six states have adopted neither a prescriber mandate for PDMP use nor statutory prescription limits. As recently as the beginning of 2017, seventeen states had not adopted either policy. Categorical state, year, and (when appropriate) quarter fixed effects, as well as fixed effects for state-level time-varying confounders including both annual demographic and economic characteristics, and state-level policies such as marijuana liberalization and Medicaid expansion, will be used to control for fixed and time-varying confounding effects. 

The event study specification makes three essential assumptions (19) that must be satisfied for causal effect identification: 

1. Parallel baseline trends are independent of exposure status. In counterfactual notation, the conditional exchangeability assumption can be written as Ya⫫A|L, which is to say that the outcome a state would have experienced (Y), at any given time with any given combination of state opioid policies (a), is independent (⫫) of the actual set of state opioid policies that the state had at that time (A), given the identified confounding variables (L). This assumption is untestable in any difference-in-difference analysis, because states are not randomized to receive the policies. However, the absence of pre-policy differential trends lends support to the assumption that post-policy trends would have been parallel if the policies had not been adopted. 

2. No anticipatory behavior prior to treatment. This is an extension of the parallel trends assumption. It holds that for all lead periods l<0, the effect of approaching treatment μ_l is 0. This is most plausible for random (exogenous) exposures. While it is reasonable to assume that prescribers and/or opioid users would not change their behavior in anticipation of upcoming legislation, it would not be unreasonable for states with worsening opioid-related outcomes to adopt more stringent controls. Either reason for pre-trends would bias estimated effects. We did not find evidence of differential trends in policy adopting states in the years prior to policy adoption. 

3. Treatment effect homogeneity. For each "cohort" of policy implementations, the effect μ_l of being in a relative timing lag period l≥0 is homogeneous regardless of absolute timing t. This assumption can only be tested in the final analysis. The presence of heterogeneous treatment effects does not invalidate results, but rather results in a weighted average of time-varying treatment effects. Several important differences exist between state-years with policies and state-years without policies (see Figure 1 for a Directed Acyclic Graph displaying these variables). As an impact evaluation seeking to estimate the causal effect of state opioid policies on opioid prescribing and opioid-related deaths, this evaluation depends on an assumption of conditional exchangeability between states that did, and did not, adopt opioid policies of interest. According to this assumption, no unmeasured confounding variables are directly associated with state opioid policies and the outcome of interest, conditional on the measured confounding variables. 

Several unmeasured time-invariant characteristics of each state (labeled "V" in Figure 1) may be linked to the outcome after policy change. For example, each state has a fixed baseline rate of the outcome that is associated with the outcome at any follow-up time. We include state fixed effects to account for these characteristics.

Within states, changes in the age structure of the population, the racial/ethnic composition of the population, the prevailing unemployment rate and employment in the manufacturing sector, and the passage of other relevant laws, such as marijuana liberalization, Medicaid expansion, and opioid-related policies such as Good Samaritan laws and naloxone access laws, may be associated both with the adoption of relevant policies and with either prescriber behavior or the risk of opioid-related mortality. 

Finally, national trends across time (labeled "U" in Figure 1), such as changing levels of opioid prescribing and mortality may also be linked to the outcome after policy change. We include year fixed effects to account for these national trends. Because national trends are not neatly summarized with a linear or quadratic trend, we will include a categorical year fixed effect.
registration_responses.q12.question:
State opioid policies: Several sources were used to code state opioid policies. The primary source for state opioid prescribing limits was a National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL) table of state prescribing limits, (20) which summarized policies enacted through April 4, 2018. Information on subsequent legislation was available through NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (21) and Ballotpedia's summary of opioid prescription limits and policies by state (22). Information on state PDMP prescriber use mandates was found in the supplement (23) to an article by Haffajee, et al., 2018 (24). That article coded PDMP policies passed through 2014; we extended their coding scheme forward for policies passed between 2015 and 2019 and included in NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (25). Detailed information on policy coding is included in Section 4, Variables. 

Opioid prescribing rates: Our primary source will be the Medicaid State Drug Utilization Data, available quarterly from 1991 to current. 

Fatal opioid poisonings: Detailed Multiple Cause of Death research files (monthly by county, 2006 to current). Opioid drug poisoning rates due to all types of opioids will be calculated using ICD-10 underlying cause codes T40.0 through T40.4 and T40.6, which refer to poisoning by opium (T40.0), heroin (T40.1), "other opioids" including natural and semi-synthetic opioids (T40.2), methadone (T40.3), synthetic opioids such as fentanyl (T40.4), and "other and unspecified narcotics" (T40.6). Code T40.5, which refers to poisoning by cocaine, is excluded as it is legally classified as a narcotic drug but is not an opioid. For secondary question 1, prescription opioids will be defined narrowly as ICD-10 code T40.2, which includes natural opioids (e.g. morphine, codeine) and semi-synthetic opioids (e.g. hydrocodone, oxycodone), which make up the majority of opioid pain killer medications (26). 

Covariates: American Community Survey (supplemented with Current Population Survey data for 2006-2007 and 2019), Ballotpedia, FRED economic data, National Conference of State Legislatures, Prescription Drug Abuse Policy System, Urban Institute.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Two major categories of state opioid prescribing policies were coded for this impact evaluation: statutory limits on opioid prescribing, and mandates for prescribers to request data from a state's PDMP. The coding scheme for specific policies is shown in Table 1. 

Statutory limits on opioid prescribing: The primary source of information for coding statutory limits on opioid prescribing was a summary table prepared by the NCSL (29). The NCSL summary table described prescription limiting statutes adopted in 21 states between the first such policy, passed in Massachusetts in 2016, and April 4, 2018. A link to the enabling legislation is included along with a short description of the limitations/requirements and any exceptions to requirements. The NCSL summary table also noted that laws had been passed in nine other states, to authorize another entity to set prescribing limits or guidelines. We filled in the remaining gaps through reference to the nonpartisan online political encyclopedia Ballotpedia, (30) and direct coding of adopted state laws receiving a code of "Prescription Drug Abuse, Prescribing Guidelines/Limits" in NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database, (31) which extends through 2019. State policies were independently coded by separate analysts, with consensus resolution of any discrepancies. 

Prescriber mandates for PDMP use: The primary source of information used to develop the coding framework for PDMP prescriber mandates came from an article by Haffajee, et al., which coded PDMP policies in all states through 2014 (32). We extended the coding scheme forward through 2019 using NCSL's Injury Prevention Legislation Database (34). Codes were checked against each state's profile as described by the Prescription Drug Monitoring Program Training and Technical Assistance Center (35). 

Exposure coding: Coding of the two types of state policy interventions will be collapsed into two levels per policy, as shown in Table 1:

 - Statutory limits on opioid prescribing will be collapsed into "some prescription limits" or "no statutory limit/guidelines only." States with statutory limits on all initial opioid prescriptions, statutory limits on certain opioid prescriptions (such as those for emergency room walk-in patients), or enforceable limits set by another agency on all or certain opioid prescriptions, will be coded as having some prescription limits. States with nonbinding guidelines or no policy will be coded as not having prescription limits. 

- Prescriber mandates for PDMP use policies will be collapsed into "PDMP use mandate" or "no PDMP use mandate." States with laws requiring physicians to consult the PDMP before writing all or some opioid prescriptions will be coded as having a PDMP use mandate. States allowing prescribers to access the PDMP but not mandating such access, or states with no PDMP available to prescribers, will be coded as not having a PDMP use mandate. 

Finally, we will test the effect of passing either type of legislation by assigning an exposure of 1 if a state has passed either a statutory limit on opioid prescribing or a prescriber mandates for PDMP use; and a 0 if a state has passed neither such policy.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Publicly Available outcome data: 

- Medicaid State Drug Utilization Data. The National Drug Code (NDC) will be used to identify opioid medications in the Medicaid State Drug Utilization data. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have released a data file permitting the conversion of prescription opioid medications to Morphine Milligram Equivalents (MME). The total MME for each state-year can therefore be calculated and standardized to the number of Medicaid patients in the state that year.

- National Center for Health Statistics Detailed Multiple Cause of Death research files. ICD-10 underlying cause-of-death codes will be analyzed to identify annual statewide deaths related to common prescription opioid medications and to all opioid drugs. The number of deaths will be treated as a Poisson random variable. 

Covariates: To prevent bias due to omitted variables that may be associated with both policy exposure and opioid prescribing and drug poisoning outcomes, the impact analysis will control for 1) additional, related state-level policies (e.g., state Medicaid expansion status and marijuana liberalization, as both medical and recreational uses), 2) state-level demographic characteristics (e.g., proportion of state residents in banded age categories and race/ethnicity categories), 3) state-level economic data (e.g., statewide unemployment rate). We will also include 4) state fixed effects to control for non-time varying unobserved heterogeneity, and 5) yearly, categorical fixed effects to control for nonlinear national trends in the outcome in states that have not adopted policies of interest. 

When a data source covers only a portion of the time period of interest (for example, ACS includes Medicaid coverage only for 2008-2018), we used regression techniques to impute missing values from alternate data sources (e.g. CPS, a smaller sample with a slightly different measure of Medicaid coverage). Additionally, because sampling-based estimation like the ACS (which is a representative 1% sample of the population each year) are subject to random error, this causes estimates to be more variable in low-population states. Therefore, we used linear mixed models to obtain smoothed estimates of time-varying demographic covariates in each state. State time-varying covariates are listed in Table 2.
registration_responses.q19.question:
The impact of each opioid policy will be estimated by comparing the changes in outcomes for states that passed the policy, to the outcomes of states that did not pass, or had not yet passed, the policy. These comparisons will be conducted using models that account for correlated residuals due to repeated observations of states. 

The following model will be fitted to the sample of students in the study, with states (i) observed at multiple time points (t):

Y_it = λ_t+α_i+∑_(l= -K)^L〖μ_l D_it^l 〗+X_it+ϵ_it

The variables in this model are defined as follows: 

Y_it = The outcome of interest Y (or a linear transformation such as a log link function for a Poisson random variable) for state i measured at time t. 

λ_t = Fixed effect for time t accounting for time trends in as-yet-untreated states. 

α_i = Fixed effect for state i accounting for unmeasured time-invariant covariates. 

l = Lead or lag times l, relative to policy adoption, with leads ranging from 1 to K or more years prior to policy passage, and lags ranging from 0 to L or more years after policy passage. 

μ_l = The mean difference-in-differences for a given lead or lag time. 

D_it^l = A series of binomial indicators indicating if a state-year observation is l years before or after policy passage. To avoid multicollinearity, the indicator for a reference lead time (l = -1) is omitted. 

X_it = A vector of state level, time-varying covariates. 

ϵ_it = State-level residual variation of outcome Y at time t.

attributes.title: Investigating the relationship between sleep quality and tactile hallucination-proneness as mediated by reality monitoring ability and negative affect.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Investigating the Relationship Between Sleep and Tactile Hallucination-Proneness as Mediated by Reality Monitoring Ability and Negative Affect

Tactile hallucinations are a highly neglected area of research within hallucination literature. However, when inferring knowledge from auditory or visual hallucinations, findings indicate that there may be an association between sleep and tactile hallucination proneness. Furthermore, negative affect and reality discrimination ability has been strongly associated to both sleep and hallucinations within other modalities. Therefore, the current study aims to investigate the relationship between sleep quality and tactile hallucination proneness in a non-clinical sample with an online methodology. In addition, negative affect and reality discrimination ability will also be examined as a potential mediator of the relationship between sleep quality and tactile hallucination proneness.

other.value:
This is a preliminary pre-registration for the purposes of a thesis-related assignment. While the majority of this information will not change, some updates may be made to the novel vibration detection task before data collection. Any changes to this will be published on this OSF project.
At the time of this pre-registration, this project has not passed ethics, however, any potential changes determined via this process will be fully documented.

sample.value: For adequate power, the current study will be aiming for at least 82 participants (giving 80% power to detect correlations of r = .30, where alpha = .05).  This will also allow us to meet Harrell’s (2001) criterion of at least 10 subjects per variable for the subsequent regression analyses. The upper limit for data collection will be N = 212, which gives reasonable levels of precision when estimating correlations that are expected in the region of r = .30 (Schonbrodt & Perugini, 2013).

analyses.value: Zero-order correlations between scores on the PSQI, PANAS-NS, tactile vibration-detection reality discrimination task, and the MUSEQ-BS subscale will be calculated. Hierarchical multiple regression analysis will be performed, with scores on the MUSEQ-BS subscale as the outcome variable. Age, gender and PSQI scores will be entered in the first step, followed by PANAS-NS scores and scores of the tactile vibration-detection task on the next step. Finally, a mediation analysis will be run, where the indirect effects of predictor variables on the outcome variable through the two potential mediator variables will be assessed.

outliers.value: Extreme outliers (scores for any of the DVs > 3.24 SD from the mean) will be excluded from the analyses. Participants who respond to fewer than 75% of the items on any of the study assessments will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable being measured for this study will be tactile hallucination-proneness. The mediator variables being measured will be negative affect and reality discrimination ability. The independent variable will be sleep.

To measure tactile hallucination-proneness, the bodily sensations subscale of the Multi-Modality Unusual Sensory Experiences Questionnaire (MUSEQ-BS) will be used, and which consists of 8 items (e.g., ‘I have felt things moving or crawling on or under my skin’).

Negative affect will be measured using the negative sub-section of the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS-NS), which consists of 10 items to be rated in a 5-point Likert scale (e.g. ‘distressed’, ‘upset’).

To measure sleep, participants will complete the self-rated questions on the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which consists of 19 items (e.g. ‘How many hours of actual sleep do you get at night?’ and ‘During the past month, how would you rate your sleep quality overall?’) within 7 components (e.g. ‘subjective sleep quality’ and ‘sleep latency’).

Reality discrimination ability will be measured using a novel, ten-trial tactile vibration detection task. Participants will be asked to enable the ‘silent vibrate’ mode on their mobile device, before scanning a QR code. The QR code will open a webpage which will sync with the online data collection session and allow notifications to be sent to participant’s phones. They will then be instructed to place their device in their trouser or skirt pocket before starting the task. Each trial will last three seconds, as indicated by the presence of a blue circle on the screen, and during which, notifications will be sent to participant’s phones with either 1 of 3 intensities (strong, light or no vibration). Immediately after the trial, participants will be asked to indicate whether they felt a strong vibration, light vibration or no vibration. In reality, no notifications will be sent to participants’ phones. Scanning the QR code will simply result in them being diverted to a GitHub webpage which was developed in a way that looks like a more complex system which will synchronize with the data collection session and send notifications to participant’s phones.

hypothesis.value:
The aim of this study is to investigate the relationship between sleep quality and tactile hallucination proneness in a non-clinical sample and online methodology, and determine the degree to which scores on the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) can account for individual’s self-reported experiences of tactile hallucinations, as reported by the bodily sensations subscale of the Multi-Modality Unusual Sensory Experiences Questionnaire (MUSEQ). Furthermore, the current study aims to investigate the potential mediating effects of reality monitoring ability on tactile hallucination proneness, as determined by a novel tactile vibration-detection task. As well as this, negative affect will also be examined as a potential mediator of the relationship between sleep quality and tactile hallucination proneness, as determined by the negative items on the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS-NA).

As is inferred from previous literature, it is hypothesised that poor sleep will be associated with higher tactile-hallucination proneness. It is also hypothesised that both negative affect and poor reality discrimination ability will mediate this relationship.
