attributes.title: Advertising in orthopaedic surgery: Do Australian orthopaedic surgeons comply with medical board guidelines?
attributes.description: Adherence to AHPRA advertisement guidelines amongst orthopaedic surgeons in Australia

q1.value: Advertising in orthopaedic surgery: Do Australian orthopaedic surgeons comply with medical board guidelines?

q3.value: Health care professionals utilise a variety of promotional activities – including direct to customer advertising – to shape patient beliefs about their services, and the benefits and harms of certain health care interventions. Given the elective nature of many orthopaedic surgeries, advertising offers a large potential to attract patients and generate revenue. In Australia, these promotional activities are governed by the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) advertising guidelines, which aim to protect patients from false or misleading claims, and facilitate informed healthcare choices.  The purpose of this study to examine adherence to the AHPRA advertisement guidelines amongst orthopaedic surgeons in Australia, who utilise the internet to advertise their services.

q4.value: A large proportion of orthopaedic surgeon advertising material in Australia does not comply with medical board guidelines.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study will be blinded to any identifiable information about the included surgeons.

question.value: This study is a cross-sectional audit that assess adherence to the AHPRA advertisement guidelines amongst Australian orthopaedic surgeons. Advertising material will be assessed based on 5 criterion, to give an overall classification of compliant or non-compliant for each surgeon.

q9.value: This is a non-randomised, observational study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Selection process 
Two methods of sampling advertising material will be used, both reflecting the different methods the general public may utilise to access information on orthopaedic surgeons.  
From a list of Australian Orthopaedic Association members, a sample of orthopaedic surgeons will be randomly selected. All online material (such as websites or social media) directly related to each included surgeon will then be collected for data inclusion.  
Second, a sample of orthopaedic surgeons from the 10 largest population areas in Australia will be obtained via a “top hit” search strategy using the Google search engine, since Google is the most commonly used search engine in Australia (Statcounter, 2019).  The key term “orthopaedic surgeon” followed by the regions name will be used to generate a list of websites. Patients are most likely to visit the first 10 webpages generated by a search engine (Eysenbach & Köhler, 2002), thus, the first page of results using default search settings will be considered for analysis. This strategy aims to identify webpages that are easily accessible and most likely to be encountered by patients.

Eligibility criteria 
Online material published by or on behalf of the selected orthopaedic surgeon relating to them or their services will be analysed.  This will usually be a website; but could include online videos, advertisements or social media pages. Sites not generated by the orthopaedic surgeon (e.g. user-generated sites), health search engines (e.g. HealthEngine, RateMDs), medical journals, news outlets and encyclopaedias will be excluded.  

Data collection process 
Relevant online material relating to each surgeon will be copied and stored electronically. Any identifiable data – including names and locations – will be redacted from the material to facilitate non-biased assessment. To maximise validity, data extraction will be piloted using a "round table" of data collectors, where disputes and uncertainties can be discussed. The remaining data collection will proceed with at least two assessors.

q13.value: Our random sample will include 81 orthopaedic surgeons.

q14.value: The survey of 81 surgeons will provide a 95% confidence level with a 10% confidence interval.

question.value:
The following proforma will be applied to the redacted online material to assess compliance to the main components of the AHPRA advertisement guidelines; for each guideline, the online material will be assessed and classified as either compliant or non-compliant: 

1. Advertisement is false, misleading, deceptive or likely to be so 
i. Makes false or inaccurate claims
ii. Uses comparison or contrast to create a false impression 
iii. Only provides partial information or omits important information
iv. Uses phrases like ‘as low as’ or ‘lowest prices’, or similar, when advertising prices, in a way which is misleading or deceptive
v. Uses words, letters or titles that may lead patients to believe a surgeon is more qualified than a holder of the same registration category

2. Offers a gift, discount or other inducement to attract a user of the health 
service without stating the terms and conditions of the offer"
i. Contains inexact price information 
ii. Does not state terms and conditions for price information, offers of discounts, or other inducements 
iii. States an instalment amount without stating the total cost 

3. Uses testimonials or purported testimonials 
i. Quotes testimonials on a website or in social media 
ii. Practitioners business website or social media allows patients to post testimonials about the practitioner 

4. Creates an unreasonable expectation of beneficial treatment
i. Creates an unreasonable expectation of treatment outcomes by exaggerating or providing biased information 
ii. Fails to disclose health risks associated with a treatment 
iii. Indicates that treatment is infallible, guaranteed, or a certain cure 
iv. Implies or states that a practitioner has an exclusive or unique skill that will benefit the patient 

5. Encourages the indiscriminate or unnecessary use of health services
i. Encourages use of services with phrases such as "don’t delay"
ii. Uses prizes, bonuses, bulk purchases, discounts or other endorsements to encourage the unnecessary consumption of health services unrelated  to clinical need or therapeutic benefit 
iii. Makes use of time-limited offers
No indices or combined measures will be used.

The primary analysis will report the proportion of compliance amongst surgeons from the random sample to each of the 5 guidelines.  Inferential statistics will be used to examine associations between levels of compliance and the state of practice, regional versus metropolitan areas, and different orthopaedic subspecialties. 
A secondary analysis will be conducted using the sample obtained via the “top hit” search strategy. The same statistical analysis will be conducted to examine associations between compliance and state of practice, regional versus metropolitan areas, and different orthopaedic subspecialties. The level of compliance will also be compared in the two samples obtained – the random selection of AOA members versus the “top hit” online search engine surgeons.

q20.value: No data transformations will be used.

q21.value: The study is a survey of compliance with known guidelines, and no direct comparisons will be made.

q22.value: We will not exclude outliers as these may be credible.

q24.value: Univariate and multivariate regression will be used to explore associations between levels of compliance and the state of practice, regional versus metropolitan areas, and different orthopaedic subspecialties.

q25.value:
References: 
Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA, 2019).  Advertising: Strategy, legislation and guidelines. Retreived from https://www.ahpra.gov.au/Publications/Advertising-resources/Legislation-guidelines.aspx

Statcounter (2019). Search Engine Market Share in Australia - August 2019. Retrieved from https://gs.statcounter.com/search-engine-market-share/all/australia

Eysenbach, G., & Köhler, C. (2002). How do consumers search for and appraise health information on the world wide web? Qualitative study using focus groups, usability tests, and in-depth interviews. BMJ, 324(7337), 573. doi:10.1136/bmj.324.7337.573

attributes.title: Exploring the dark side of democracy

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Exploring the dark side of democracy

other.value:
INDEPENDENT VARIABLES: 

We will also analyze how moral behavior is affected by (a) beliefs (b) political orientation (c) moral identity (d) student (e) employment status (f) gender (g) age. 

(a)	Beliefs 

We measure beliefs for each moral issue, by asking participants what they expect the other participants in their group to choose. 
Beliefs are measured with the following questions: 

Majority voting: 
Beliefs of being pivotal: Participants answer how likely they think it is that 2 other group members chose Option A, and that 2 other group members chose option B. 
Beliefs of others’ decisions: Participants indicate how many of the other 4 group members they think chose A and how many chose B. 

Median voting: 
Beliefs of being pivotal (question in both conditions): Participants answer how likely they think that their proposal/decision was the middle value of all five proposals/decisions. 
Beliefs of others’ decisions (question in both conditions): Participants indicate how many participants they believe proposed/chose to extract more, less, or the same amount as they. 

(b)	Political orientation 
Participants respond to the short version of the Cultural Cognition Worldview Group scale (CCWVG) with 6 items. Participants answer on a six-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree). A high score indicates a more individualistic worldview, whereas a low score indicates a more collectivistic worldview. Average score will be used as the independent variable. 

(c)	Moral identity 
Participants respond to the Moral Identity Scale (Aquino and Reed, 2002) with 10 items. Two dimensions of moral identity are measured: internalization and symbolization. Participants answer on a seven-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). A high score on internalization indicate that moral principles are central to one’s self-concept. A high score on symbolization reflects that moral principles are expressed outwardly to others to a high degree. Average score will be used as the independent variable.

(d) Student
(e) Employment status
(f) Gender 
(g) Age

MEDIAN VOTING 

Moral behavior. The dependent variable is moral behavior. It is measured using the following task. Participants choose how much they want to extract from a donation to charity, by using a continuous scale between 0-30. conditions.value:
MAJORITY VOTING 

Each participant is randomly assigned to one of two conditions: 

1. Majority voting condition: Participant are together with 4 other participants from Prolific i.e. in a group of 5 people. Each participant votes whether or not they want to donate to charity. The option that the majority votes for is implemented for all group members. The choices and the consequences are the same for all 5 participants in the group. 

2. Individual condition: Participant are together with 4 other participants from Prolific i.e. in a group of 5 people. Each participant chooses individually whether or not they want to donate to charity. Each person in the group will have their own decision implemented. 

MEDIAN VOTING
 
Each participant is randomly assigned to one of two conditions: 

1. Median voting condition: Participant are together with 4 other participants from Prolific i.e. in a group of 5 people. Each person in the group proposes an amount to extract from the donation, between 0 and 30 tokens. All 5 proposals are sorted from smallest to largest value. The value in the middle is then selected: everyone in the group receives that amount as payment. 

2. Individual condition: Participant are together with 4 other participants from Prolific i.e. in a group of 5 people. Each person in the group chooses an amount to extract from the donation, between 0 and 30 tokens. Everyone in the group receives the amount they choose to extract as payment. 

There are four conditions in total, and one participant can only be assigned to one of these four conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Main research question: How does voting affect moral decisions? 

Following the idea of the diffusion of responsibility theory (H1) and low cost theory of expressive voting (H2) we test two conflicting hypotheses: 

H1: Voting increases immoral behavior.
H2: Voting decreases immoral behavior. 

We investigate our main research question in two separate research questions: 
RQ 1: How does majority voting affect moral behavior? 
RQ 2. How does a median voting rule affect moral behavior?

attributes.title: Goal Focus, Goal Progress, and Motivation

q1.value: When focusing on “how” vs. “why” benefits long-term pursuit of weight loss.

q3.value:
Findings from two 6-week longitudinal studies suggest that it may be beneficial to instruct individuals to focus on the process of goal pursuit while pursuing long-term goals (Freund and Hennecke, 2012; Hennecke and Freund, 2014). In particular, findings suggested that focusing on how to lose weight, rather than focusing on weight loss itself, might enhance self-regulation (e.g., improved dietary adherence), which can play a key role in long-term behavioral change. It is suggested that a process focus may be especially beneficial for goal pursuit when one experiences setbacks (Kaftan and Freund, 2018). More research is needed to determine whether the benefits of process-based strategies generalize to other behavioral contexts (e.g., exercise), and if the effects outlast the study or intervention period.

The present study expands on this work by examining how individuals’ focus on process- and outcome-based goals is related to goal-pursuit in a naturalistic setting. This study will examine data from weekly journals that gym members complete as part of a workout challenge at their local gym. We will assess the extent to which participants focus on process and outcome goals during the challenge, and how that relates over time to perceptions of goal progress, attitudes towards weight-loss, motivation, workout attendance, and weight loss during an 8-week weight-loss challenge at a gym. We will also receive workout attendance from gyms for participating members that details the number of workouts members completed 8 weeks prior to the start of the challenge, during the challenge, and after the end of the challenge.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through fitness studios in Minnesota. These studios are hosting an 8-week workout challenge. The gym manager has given the study team permission to ask individuals who have signed up for the challenge if they will allow the study team to obtain data from online journals they complete as part of the challenge. We will also ask participants if they give us permission to obtain their anthropometric measurements and workout attendance from their gym. Individuals’ decisions to volunteer their data will have no bearing on their ability to participate in the workout challenge. 
Gym members will be presented with information about the study and a consent form when they complete their first online journal for the workout challenge. Their data will only be made accessible to the study team if they consent to participate.
Data will be collected from consenting participants’ online journals each week. The journals participants are completing are included with supplemental materials. For consenting participants, we will receive anthropometric measurements and workout attendance from the gyms. Data collection will take place over 8 weeks.

attributes.title: Thinking aloud while watching a witness testify in an alleged rape case
attributes.description: This study investigates what mock jurors are thinking when they watch the victim's testimony in a case of alleged rape

q1.value: Thinking aloud while watching a witness testify in an alleged rape case

q2.value: Harrison Lee, Blake McKimmie, Barbara Masser, Jason M Tangen

q3.value:
The aim of the first study in this program of research was to test how mock jurors evaluated the testimony of a rape victim when it was presented chronologically or with the rape event first. Participants’ evaluations (i.e., whether the events described in the testimony depicted rape or consensual sex) were measured every second as they watched the video of the victim testifying. Specifically, participants moved a slider between two scale endpoints (1 = consensual sex, 100 = rape) when responding to this measure. Using this design, we investigated how participants evaluated the overall testimony by recording the position of the slider at the end of the video. We also investigated how participants evaluated specific events described in this testimony (i.e., the rape event), by recording the position of the slider during certain parts of the video. Contrary to our predictions, participants in both testimony conditions did not differ in how they evaluated the overall testimony. However, participants who watched the testimony where the rape event was presented first evaluated this event as more depictive of rape compared to those who watched the testimony presented in a chronological order.

Furthermore, the results of the study described above showed that the order in which the testimony was presented to participants influenced the variability in their responses regarding whether the events described by the victim were evaluated as rape or consensual sex. When the testimony was presented chronologically, participants converged in their responses using the slider (i.e., moved the slider less often and less extremely between perceiving the testimony as depicting consensual sex or rape) while they watched the victim testify. Conversely, participants were far less consistent when the rape event was presented first in the testimony – that is, participants were much more variable in their responses using the slider (i.e., moved the slider more often and more extremely between perceiving the testimony as depicting consensual sex or rape). 

Since participants’ responses to how they evaluated the victim’s testimony were restricted by the question asked of them (i.e., participants were only able to indicate whether they thought the events described depicted rape or consensual sex), we are somewhat limited in terms of our interpretation of this unexpected result. Specifically, we do not know why participants struggled to decide whether the events described by the victim depicted rape or consensual sex when they watch the rape-first version of the testimony. In a review, Ericsson and Simon (1980) argue that the use of think aloud procedures – that is, having participants say out loud their thoughts while they complete a task – can determine the exact cognitive processes a participant uses to come to a decision. Further, such procedures stop the participant from reporting what they think the experimenter wants them to report in a task, as their response is not restricted by a specific question (e.g., do these events depict consensual sex or rape?). As such, if we were to ask participants to think aloud as they watch and interpret the victim’s testimony, their utterances during this task should reflect their authentic interpretations of the testimony (Charters, 2003). This data may then allow us to understand why participants’ evaluations vary in different versions of the victim’s testimony.    

The aim of the current study is investigate what participants are thinking when they interpret the victim’s testimony. Specifically, participants will be asked to think aloud while watching a testimony that is presented with the rape event first or the same testimony presented in chronological order. Participants’ verbal responses to this task will be recorded and then transcribed, so that their utterances are paired to the time of the video in which they were said. These transcriptions will then be analysed in order to investigate whether participants who watch the rape-first version of the victim’s testimony interpret the events described differently to those who watch the chronological testimony.

q4.value: This study will be somewhat exploratory in nature. Although we expect that participants who watch the rape-first version of the testimony will likely interpret the events described differently to those who watch the chronological testimony – we, however, will not make any specific predictions on how they will differ. Instead, participants’ responses to the think aloud measure will be analysed using a data driven thematic analysis using Leximancer software.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to one of two conditions to form the between-subjects manipulation of testimony order (chronological testimony, rape event first testimony). The key dependent variables in this study include participants’ responses to the think aloud task, the choice of verdict measure and the guilt likelihood measure.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to watch either the chronological testimony or the rape event first testimony. During the experiment, participants will be assigned either the number “2” or the number “1”. If participants are assigned the number “2”, they will be assigned to watch the rape-first version of the testimony. If they are assigned the number “1”, they will be assigned to watch the chronological testimony. This randomisation occurs in the programming script of the study and so participants are not aware of this allocation process.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be students recruited from the first-year research participation scheme at the University of Queensland. Participants will be excluded from participating in the study if they are under 18 years of age. This exclusion criterion is necessary as the minimum age to serve on a jury in Australia is 18 years old. On the first-year research participation scheme website, students will see advertisements for a number of studies that they can participant in for course credit. If a student is eligible to participate, they can book in a time to complete the study which will be conducted in a laboratory owned by one of the researchers.

q13.value: We will recruit 39 participants from the first year research participation scheme.

q14.value: According to Braun and Clarke (2013), a sample size of 39 participants will be sufficient to identify the underlying themes and patterns present in the data. There is, however, another reason for this target sample size. This study is being conducted as part of a wider project, which involves a second study with separate research questions (you can find more information about this study at https://osf.io/a43y7). Specifically, after participants watch the video of the victim’s testimony, they will be asked to retell what they think happened on the night of the alleged rape they just heard about. Their response to this task will be recorded. These recordings will then be used as stimuli in the other study. To ensure that this other study is sufficiently powered, 39 recordings will need to be collected from participants in the current study.

question.value: We will manipulate testimony order by varying the order in which the victim describes the events in her testimony. In the chronological testimony, the victim will describe the events as they happened on the night of the alleged rape (i.e., the events which occurred before the alleged rape followed by the rape event). In the rape-first version of the testimony, the victim will first describe the rape event followed by the events which occurred before the rape (please see attached "videos" for links to these videos on YouTube).

Before participants watch the video of the victim’s testimony, they will be given the following instructions, “Please imagine that you are serving on a jury in a trial where the defendant, Neil Fox, is accused of rape. In this trial, you will hear evidence from Janine Jenker who has accused the defendant of raping her. You will shortly watch a video of Janine’s testimony. As you watch this video, we would like you to think aloud – that is, say out loud exactly what you are thinking about the events being described by Janine. Just like we practiced in the tutorial (to watch this tutorial, please refer to the attached “videos”), when any thought comes into your mind while you watch this video, please say it out loud.” Participants will then watch the video of the victim’s testimony. When this video starts playing, the participant’s response to the think aloud task will start being recorded. This recording will then be transcribed so that the statements made by the participant are paired with the time of the video in which they were said (to see an example of this procedure, please refer to the attached “transcription example”). 

Choice of verdict will be assessed using a single item: “Now please decide whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of rape.” Participants may answer this question by selecting either “guilty” or “not guilty”. 

 Guilt likelihood will be assessed using a single item: “How likely is it that Neil Fox (the defendant) is guilty of committing rape” with participants responding on a 1 (not at all) to 7 (very) scale, with higher scores denoting greater guilt.

The manipulation of testimony order will be assessed by one item: “At what point during the video did you hear Janine discuss the defendant forcing her down and penetrating her?” with participants responding on a 1 (very early in the video) to 7 (very late in the video) scale.
An independent samples t-test will be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the manipulation check measure.

q22.value: No awareness checks will be performed. Participants will be excluded from the analyses if they do not respond to the think aloud task. Participants will also be excluded from the final sample if they do not respond to the dependent or manipulation check measures.

q23.value: Any missing data will be treated under the guidelines of Pigott (2001), where participants will be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.

q24.value: Participants’ responses to the testimony think aloud measure will be analysed using a text analytics tool (e.g., Leximancer) to identify common words, themes, and higher level concepts. Participants’ responses will be split into distinct groups so that the themes we identify in one group can be compared to the themes that we identify in another. Specifically, participants’ responses may be split based on the condition they were assigned to and the verdict they decided for the defendant. We may also divide participants’ responses based on when they were made during the video of the victim’s testimony. Specifically, participants’ responses made during the victim’s description of the rape event may be split into one group. Whereas, participants’ responses made during the victim’s description of the events that occurred before the alleged rape may be split into another group.

q25.value:
Charters, E. (2003). The use of Think-aloud Methods in Qualitative Research an Introduction to Think-Aloud Methods. Brock Education Journal, 12(2), 68-82. https://doi.org/10.26522/brocked.v12I2.38

Clarke, V., & Braun, V. (2013) Successful qualitative research: A practical guide for beginners. Sage.

Ericsson, K. A., & Simon, H. A. (1980). Verbal reports as data. Psychological Review, 87(3), 215–251. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.87.3.215

registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomly allocated to watch either the chronological testimony or the rape event first testimony. During the experiment, participants will be assigned either the number “2” or the number “1”. If participants are assigned the number “2”, they will be assigned to watch the rape-first version of the testimony. If they are assigned the number “1”, they will be assigned to watch the chronological testimony. This randomisation occurs in the programming script of the study and so participants are not aware of this allocation process.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will recruit 39 participants from the first year research participation scheme.
registration_responses.q14: According to Braun and Clarke (2013), a sample size of 39 participants will be sufficient to identify the underlying themes and patterns present in the data. There is, however, another reason for this target sample size. This study is being conducted as part of a wider project, which involves a second study with separate research questions (you can find more information about this study at https://osf.io/a43y7). Specifically, after participants watch the video of the victim’s testimony, they will be asked to retell what they think happened on the night of the alleged rape they just heard about. Their response to this task will be recorded. These recordings will then be used as stimuli in the other study. To ensure that this other study is sufficiently powered, 39 recordings will need to be collected from participants in the current study.
registration_responses.q22: No awareness checks will be performed. Participants will be excluded from the analyses if they do not respond to the think aloud task. Participants will also be excluded from the final sample if they do not respond to the dependent or manipulation check measures.
registration_responses.q23: Any missing data will be treated under the guidelines of Pigott (2001), where participants will be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.
registration_responses.q24: Participants’ responses to the testimony think aloud measure will be analysed using a text analytics tool (e.g., Leximancer) to identify common words, themes, and higher level concepts. Participants’ responses will be split into distinct groups so that the themes we identify in one group can be compared to the themes that we identify in another. Specifically, participants’ responses may be split based on the condition they were assigned to and the verdict they decided for the defendant. We may also divide participants’ responses based on when they were made during the video of the victim’s testimony. Specifically, participants’ responses made during the victim’s description of the rape event may be split into one group. Whereas, participants’ responses made during the victim’s description of the events that occurred before the alleged rape may be split into another group.
registration_responses.q25:
Charters, E. (2003). The use of Think-aloud Methods in Qualitative Research an Introduction to Think-Aloud Methods. Brock Education Journal, 12(2), 68-82. https://doi.org/10.26522/brocked.v12I2.38

Clarke, V., & Braun, V. (2013) Successful qualitative research: A practical guide for beginners. Sage.

Ericsson, K. A., & Simon, H. A. (1980). Verbal reports as data. Psychological Review, 87(3), 215–251. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.87.3.215
registration_responses.q8.question: Participants will be randomly allocated to one of two conditions to form the between-subjects manipulation of testimony order (chronological testimony, rape event first testimony). The key dependent variables in this study include participants’ responses to the think aloud task, the choice of verdict measure and the guilt likelihood measure.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be students recruited from the first-year research participation scheme at the University of Queensland. Participants will be excluded from participating in the study if they are under 18 years of age. This exclusion criterion is necessary as the minimum age to serve on a jury in Australia is 18 years old. On the first-year research participation scheme website, students will see advertisements for a number of studies that they can participant in for course credit. If a student is eligible to participate, they can book in a time to complete the study which will be conducted in a laboratory owned by one of the researchers.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate testimony order by varying the order in which the victim describes the events in her testimony. In the chronological testimony, the victim will describe the events as they happened on the night of the alleged rape (i.e., the events which occurred before the alleged rape followed by the rape event). In the rape-first version of the testimony, the victim will first describe the rape event followed by the events which occurred before the rape (please see attached "videos" for links to these videos on YouTube).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Before participants watch the video of the victim’s testimony, they will be given the following instructions, “Please imagine that you are serving on a jury in a trial where the defendant, Neil Fox, is accused of rape. In this trial, you will hear evidence from Janine Jenker who has accused the defendant of raping her. You will shortly watch a video of Janine’s testimony. As you watch this video, we would like you to think aloud – that is, say out loud exactly what you are thinking about the events being described by Janine. Just like we practiced in the tutorial (to watch this tutorial, please refer to the attached “videos”), when any thought comes into your mind while you watch this video, please say it out loud.” Participants will then watch the video of the victim’s testimony. When this video starts playing, the participant’s response to the think aloud task will start being recorded. This recording will then be transcribed so that the statements made by the participant are paired with the time of the video in which they were said (to see an example of this procedure, please refer to the attached “transcription example”). 

Choice of verdict will be assessed using a single item: “Now please decide whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of rape.” Participants may answer this question by selecting either “guilty” or “not guilty”. 

 Guilt likelihood will be assessed using a single item: “How likely is it that Neil Fox (the defendant) is guilty of committing rape” with participants responding on a 1 (not at all) to 7 (very) scale, with higher scores denoting greater guilt.

The manipulation of testimony order will be assessed by one item: “At what point during the video did you hear Janine discuss the defendant forcing her down and penetrating her?” with participants responding on a 1 (very early in the video) to 7 (very late in the video) scale.
registration_responses.q19.question: An independent samples t-test will be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the manipulation check measure.
